Chad Woolley wrote:

> J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>  > Chad Woolley wrote:
>  >
>  >
>  >>> This is a situation where Aspect-Oriented Programming might be useful
>  >>> after all.
>  >>>
>  >
>  > <snip />
>  >
>  >>> AOP could be well suited for this type of task, because otherwise you
>  >>> would have to duplicate this monitoring code (or at least remember to
>  >>> duplicate a call to it) in each test method.
>  >
>  >
>  > What if you just extended TestCase and made all your tests extend that
>  > new implementation? Would that work? Isn't that how JUnitPerf works?
> 
> 
> Yes.  However, my note was saying that the framework-extension approach 
> may not
> (easily) work in some cases.  For example, if your fixture-setup in your
> TestCases took much longer, relatively, than the actual execution time 
> of the
> Class Under Test.  This could cause (relatively) slight variances in the
> fixture-setup times to obscure (relatively) large variances in the 
> excution time
> of your Class Under Test.

Then I would override runBare() to generate more events: one after 
setUp() and one before tearDown(), then augment TestListener, then have 
the test monitor implement the bigger TestListener interface. All you 
need are two more events, and since you can fix that in one place....

It's entirely possible that JUnit-addons Test Runner already does this.

Understand, I'm not trying to squash your enthusiasm for AOP. You just 
have that Golden Hammer look in your eye.... :)
